Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: My headset itched against my ear as I dialed another number, the sales dashboard blinking green—my numbers were soaring, and I was on track to crush this week’s quota. Management would be thrilled. But as I prepared my next pitch, my phone buzzed with frantic messages from the activist group chat. The protest I’d helped organize was taking a turn: police were blocking exits, and panic was rising. I was supposed to help coordinate a safe response, to be there for my friends and the cause I believed in. My manager’s voice echoed in my head—“Don’t lose momentum, every call counts!”—while my activist friends pleaded for guidance and calm. My heart pounded, torn between the responsibility to my job and the urgent need to protect my fellow activists. I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, my hand frozen between the call button and my phone, caught in the impossible tug-of-war between two worlds that demanded all of me, right now.
